bibl.title: Letter from Charles E. Magoon to William Crawford Gorgas, June 1, 1905

div1.p: Magoon writes about yellow fever cases in the Canal Zone. He makes an official offer of full financial and manpower support for Gorgas to eradicate the disease.

div1.head: Letter from Charles E. Magoon to William Crawford Gorgas, June 1, 1905
div1.p:
Today's yellow fever report from your office has just
been handed to me.

I notice that since May 12th cases of yellow fever
have occurred in four localities on the Isthmus, to wit:
the City of Panama, Colon, Gorgona and Culebra.

I understand that the case at Gorgona on May 24th
was the first one from that locality. It is not established that
the man was infected at Gorgona as there was opportunity for him
to be infected elsewhere.

The disturbing feature of the present situation is
that opportunity has arisen for the mosquitoes to become infect-
ed in four localities. It occurs to me that this may necessit-
ate an expansion of your force and an increase of your facilit-
ies for stamping out the disease. This thought presses home
upon me by reason of the fact that J. B.J. Rensing, the American
engineer at Culebra, was taken sick May 23rd but was not
admitted to Ancon hospital until May 29th.

I understand it is difficult to recognize yellow
fever in its early stages, and that in mild cases the difficulty
continues for a longer period, and possibly this furnishes the
explanation of the length of time between the initial period of
2.
his illness and his admission to the hospital. But there are a
great many non-immunes at Culebra, and I should like to be
advised whether or not the condition requires an increase in
the number of doctors stationed at that point in order that
more frequent inspections and critical examinations may be made.

I have heretofore advised you, and I wish to repeat
with added emphasis, that the entire resources available to the
Isthmian Canal Commission, and the Government of the Canal Zone,
are available to render you all possible assistance in the
great work of eradicating yellow fever on the Isthmus and ex-
pediting the accomplishment of proper sanitation. I know
I voice the earnest conviction of the President and the Secreta-
ry of War in saying that yellow fever must be eradicated and
proper sanitation accomplished, if it is within the possibility
of human endeavor. Money, means and men, to the extent of the
Commission's ability to supply them, are at your disposal. We
rely upon you to ascertain and determine what is required. By
“we” I mean the President, the Secretary of War, the Commission,
and the people of the United States.

I do not consider the present situation unduly alar-
ming, but think the present hazard much less than at several
previous periods.

I am addressing you thus formally simply to put in
writing what I have stated to you verbally, and to preclude
3.
the possibility of there being any hesitation on your part in
requesting extraordinary remedies now or at any time hereafter
when you may think they are required.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, signed Charles E. Magoon
Governor. The Chief Sanitary Officer
Panama
Ancon
June 1st 1905
Panama
Magoon Chas E.
Governor
To Chief of Sanitation
Col. W.C. Gorgas
